If art is your thing, and it should be if you visit Santa Fe, you should visit this museum.

Note:  If time permits, you should buy a museum pass which allows you to visit all of Santa Fe's excellent public museums, including the Native Arts, Folk Art , Hispanic and History museums

This is a nice museum near the Plaza. It opened in 1917 and has NM artwork dating back to that era. There are classic, well known artists (o'Keefe / Baumann) on display, as well as, newer / less known artists. Don't rush through the courtyard near the entrance -- the murals are very beautiful and were commissioned in the 1930s (still look amazing).

When you want to take a break from the Santa Fe sales pitch, mall-like commercialism or just the heat of the day, stop into the New Mexico Museum of Art.  The walls of the museum portray a multitude of stories as seen through the eyes of the artists who have been inspired by the people and landscapes of New Mexico.  The magnificent building is also a work of art.  Take the time to appreciate the detailed murals in the auditorium and courtyard which capture New Mexico history and culture.  The Colors of the Southwest exhibit gave me a new appreciation of the artistic diversity and broad range of the New Mexico palette.

While not necessarily a featured museum in various guides, it is worth at least an hour of your time. This museum was included in our combo tickets for Santa Fe Museums. We spent about 2-1/2 hours here.

There are some very interesting art, particularly sculpture, not seen in other Santa Fe museums. The murals in the atrium are particularly interesting.

Stopped by and they had  the exhibit: The birth, death and resurrection of Christ. It was excellent, as was the rest of the collection. Might not be the biggest display but it was very nice and staff was very friendly.
Museum of art Santa Fe:  A larger space than the O’Keefe museum.  Eclectic mix of modern and contemporary work.  The building itself is work of art. Yes yes yes.

Being right off the plaza, makes this "must see" museum an easy to get to museum!  We were there just as an amazing Agnes Pelton exhibit was winding down (on it's way to the Whitney NY peeps).  The murals in the atria are so beautiful.  Take your time and enjoy.  Lots of good stuff to see here.

This is a small museum with a large collection but only a very small part of the collection on display.  I was suprised by the limited number of art works on display and even more surprised by what was on display-  lesser quality art than what is seen in most of the galleries in town.    

I had read that this museum had a number of Georgia O'Keefe's.  But not one was on display.  When I asked at the entrance desk, I was told that the museum did indeed own a number of O'Keefe's but that none were on display.  

I would skip this museum.  It isn't worth a visit.

name: Hyde Memorial State Park
reviews: Use hking shoes for trails, but there are also turnouts that afford incredible views across the miles wide valley.  The drive up and through the forest is stunning.

Hyde park is just a few miles away from the city yet it feels like hours away, the scenery changes from homes and dirt to creeks and trees and beautiful rocks. The hiking trails are great and if you're around the first couple weeks of October the views of the Aspens changing colors is amazing.

We stumbled upon this park last minute and we’re glad we did! It’s in such a beautiful natural rustic setting close to Santa Fe! We hit it just right for the fall foliage. The most gorgeous scenery I’ve ever laid my eyes on. Go to the top of the mountain and pay the money to ride tram to the top! It’s $15 a person but so worth it for the pics you’ll have. Great place for camping or picnicking which we did. Get off the beaten path and do this:-)

Definitely recommend! The views are amazing! Park along the way and get onto the many trails for a hike. There are many places to pull over, but be careful because any drivers may stop in the middle of the road! The views are so amazing that I think people sometimes forget they are driving! I haven't seen any accidents, but it is something to be aware of. Enjoy the drive and take lots of photos!
When to a wedding at the Park, was really nice up in the mountains,the weather is colder than sante fe , take a jacket, nice place and has a campground near by.

We hiked the Circle Trail and were so glad we did.  We parked at the trailhead where there is also a ski/snowboard shop and got a little information before we headed out.  We paid the $5 to park since it’s State Forest property and headed out - or should I say up?  We hiked up for a long time - the sign at the bottom warns you to be prepared to go up 1000 feet.  My sister’s fit bit said we hiked a total of 7 miles and went up 133 floors.  We accidentally took the short .25 Waterfall trail which was amazing since there was still ice on it and we got to walk on the semi frozen stream.  It was worth the short hike in and out since you just go to the waterfall and turn around.  We saw many dogs with great owners sharing the trails.  Dress in layers and take water and go early so you can follow the trail.  It’s not well marked but we just followed the obvious trail and confirmed when we saw a sign or bench.  It was a challenge with the elevation and climb, but take your time and take breaks to enjoy the views. Beautiful day just outside Santa Fe!

We camped here for spring break with our young kids.  Pros: mountains and views spectacular, near Ski Santa Fe so can easily access the ski slopes quickly. Camp host and park rangers very nice and helpful.  Cons: only electric camp sites, has pit toilet.  No showers/bathrooms.  1 water main available up at the camp office only.
The grandeur of the view was breathtaking.  Great hiking trails in the summer time. Can’t go to a Santa Fe without a drive up the park. You will be glad you did.

Hyde Memorial State Park is small but nice.  We stopped at one of the fee stations upon arrival and deposited the envelope provided with auto information and a five-dollar bill. The visitor center was closed when we arrived and was still closed when we left -- I guess a mid-week day in October is off season.  Hyde Memorial SP looks like a great park for camping.
  
The trails we took were well-maintained.  I was a little disappointed that so few aspens had changed color, but Mother Nature cannot be controlled.  We visited a couple of days before Santa Fe's first frost; I'm sure the park had more gold color a few days later.

Having just moved to the Santa Fe area, I've had multiple people tell me that I must go to Hyde Park. 
I was blown away! Firstly, the thing that most impressed me is the number of picnic areas and group picnic/camp areas. They were everywhere. So arriving late on a weekend, chances are, there will be something available. But the interesting aspect of this, is the trees & vegetation are so think, very unlike down lower in town, each picnic spot retains a healthy amount of privacy. Very good planning.

Secondly, the roads & access roads are well maintained. They are well graded, sided and I seriously couldn't find any potholes or washboard. Again, impressive.

And thirdly, the trails are wonderful. There aren't too many, but they are taken care of, never too far from the road and well signed. 
Hyde State Park is what I think of when I envision a state park. Excellent job New Mexico!

Loved the forest and how much more green it was here. We followed a trail that was next to a creek. It varied from very rocky to mountain meadow with flowers and butterflies. I loved that there were no bugs! Instead of gnats flying around me, I was encircled by small moths. It was quite surreal. Bring water and I would say that you should be in fairly good shape. I run several miles every day, and had to stop and rest several times. Granted, I am from the east coast, so the elevation was getting to me.

name: Old Fort Marcy Park
address: 617 Paseo de Peralta Also access it by traveling 3 blocks up Artist Rd. and turning right
reviews: Lots of historical plaques along the trail which were really cool. Walked back after dinner and heard the coyotes crying.

Whether you brave the steps and pathway up the hill from Paseo de Peralta or enjoy the nearly level path from the parking area off of Kearney Ave, the walk to the cross affords an incredible view of the city and distant areas.  It is especially rewarding at night when it cools down a bit and the gentle breezes keep you cool while looking at the city lights and possibly a distant lightning show.

Adjacent to Cross of the Martyrs, atop a hill overlooking Santa Fe.  Gave us an appreciation for the mountains that are so close to Santa Fe in many directions.  Fort Marcy was built in 1846 at the beginning of the Mexican-American War by the U.S. Army following the invasion and capture of the Mexican city of Santa Fe.  Fort Marcy was meant to protect the troops in case of a local uprising but never garrisoned soldiers or witnessed any gunfire.  Guns were, in fact, removed by the end of 1847 and the adobe walls began the slow process of erosion.

Our visit prompted us to think about the very different cultures that have confronted each other in Santa Fe over many years.

It's held in Marcy Park. Google for details. But you must go to get rid of of all the old stuff once! Can't miss! We locals love to chant burn burn. His eyes glow and he roars. Just the best! And you can put your one message as they build him. Way cool!
I would encourage all Santa Fe visitors to take this in. It is a beautiful spot and I learned so much about the local history on the plaques along the walk. Very inspiring!

We didn't spend much time here because it had snowed the day before and was very cold. We drove to the top and walked the pathway to the cross. Nice, informative signs are placed around the park. Great view of Santa Fe and the Sangre de Christo mountains.
It's the grounds and park only, no buildings. There is a driveway with parking, but walking up the hill is a great workout and there are plaques with history along the way. Nice picnic area up top.
Great place to view the city and surrounding mountains. One can easily see why the fort was built at this location. You can get some good exercise walking the trail from Paseo de Peralta the fort.

name: Wheelwright Museum of the American Indian
reviews: Happened on an exhibit of Melanie Yazzie and enjoyed the wonderful video they had of her, and of other artists exhibiting in their unbelievable jewelry exhibit.  The descriptions of the work and quotes from the artists throughout the museum made it a real pleasure.

We have enjoyed this museum on countless visit -- it's small but each exhibit is well focused and well curated and very informative. It's like visiting a private collection and is more intimate than the larger museums and their gift shop is one of the best anywhere. Lots of authentic southwest gifts at reasonable prices and a very helpful staff.

The Wheelwright is shaped like a hogan and showcases a small but always distinctive collection in its changing exhibit cases.  Downstairs is the Case Trading Post which offers Native American wares from the region in a reproduction of an authentic post.

It's an incredibly interesting little museum with great exhibits. Every time they have a new exhibit they completely transform the interior space. Wonderful story behind the museum's origins and the Trading Post downstairs should not be missed.
There was a superb exhibition of arts my contemporary Native Americans. it was fascinating to see how the current generation adapts tradition to coment on the current age.
This Native American museum was very well done.  They have a jewelry exhibit of Native American jewelry that was amazing.  They also had some interesting art.  Well worth a visit.
I’m glad I stumbled upon this museum. I love Native American jewelry, and they have an amazing collection here.

I know this is a Museum, and the exhibits can be really great or just ok.  It’s a small museum so they can do some really different exhibits you will never see elsewhere.

BUT THE BEST THING ABOUT IT IS THE TRADING POST DOWNSTAIRS.  Not if you are looking for trinkets and minor items, but if you are looking for genuine quality, by known and respected artisans, and books you will read, and art you will hang on the wall, this is the place to shop.

name: Railyard Arts District
address: South Guadalupe Street Between Agua Fria and Paseo de Peralta
reviews: Explored the Railyards district's restaurants (we ate at Tomasita's and Whole Hog bbq, both excellent), curio and collectible shops, art galleries, and Site Santa Fe art museum, well worth the admission of $10 general and $5 students and seniors. Nothing but restaurants open after 4 or 5 on weekdays, at least in winter, but plenty of time to explore during the day and no crowds! We stayed at the Sage Inn, an easy 1 block walk away, so we had easy access to go back a few times.
Whether its the Saturday morning Farmer's Market, REI fix, great modern art museums, cool clothing, quaint restaurants or upscale hair salon - this is the place to find it all in Santa Fe!

Has the best contemporary art galleries in town, great movie theater the violet crown, farmers market and great restaurants. Oh I forgot shops like REI and chicos...
If you only have limited time  to spend in Santa Fe, go hang out here. In summer you also have live music !

Sana Fe is known for its many galleries, but the Railyard District is now home to several modern, bright galleries offering artists from around the world. galleryFRITZ, Charlotte Jackson, Evoke, and SITE Santa FE are some of my favorites. Plus, the Farmer's Market is on-site and REI and Violet Crown Cinema, too.
This is a good place to walk around stretching your legs while seeing cool unique things to buy. The Sunday market is my favorite time to visit due to the availability of different wares
Railyard area brings in the train from Albuquerque. This area includes the farmers market, a handful of restaurants and shopping. Violet Crowne is a main attraction here.

I went to the Sunday Market. I liked the selection of art work there.  It is a big, sunny building. Each artist has enough room to showcase their wares.  I liked being able to talk to the artists, something that doesn’t really happen in most galleries.
Everything that you could want is here: red chilis, ristras, baked goods, jewelry, and fresh produce.

name: Santa Fe Botanical Garden
reviews:
We absolutely adored this garden!! It is a lovely time of year, so roses are in full bloom, and lavender is coming into full bloom. But what added to the beauty of the garden is the bronze statue exhibit that has been placed all thru the garden. The statues are from different artists and of different genres, yet they fit so beautifully, and they pull your eye to different perspectives in the garden. 
We spent a couple of hours there, and our only wish was that the garden was bigger. 
Highly recommend, at least thru the time if this exhibit, which is till May 2020. 
Docents are available to answer questions and are very knowledgeable

Went right after opening on Sunday-would recommended then or during the week to avoid crowds and kids.   Relaxing and currently they have a fabulous sculpture exhibit tucked into the gardens.  Gift shop is small but great.  Wear a hat, sunscreen and probably bring water if you aren’t used to the Southwest

I brought my children here for nature journaling. There was one of the best ethnic botanical heritage installations I have ever seen, although small a very pleasant experience. The bronze art sculptures of wildlife are striking and beautiful to complement the gardens. There is quite a bit of seasonal variation and perhaps best visited in Spring and Summer seasons. A great place to stop on Museum Hill while visiting other sites.

Keep in mind what this garden is:  high desert at high altitude.  As a result, you may (or may not) enjoy this garden in the winter.  For those of us who are curious about what plants look like in their dormant stage and what "winter interest" they can bring to a garden, it's very good.  I hope they keep adding more plants to this garden that retain an interesting shape or color throughout the winter.  I'm sure they will as this garden is relatively new.  It may get an "excellent" from me next year.

It also is a very good site for viewing attractive ways to incorporate zuni bowls and other methods of water diversion into your landscape. 

Late spring, summer and fall are probably more interesting to the general public.   It is still small, so don't expect to spend hours here.

Keep in mind what this garden is:  high desert at high altitude.  As a result, you may (or may not) enjoy this garden in the winter.  For those of us who are curious about what plants look like in their dormant stage and what "winter interest" they can bring to a garden, it's very good.  I hope they keep adding more plants to this garden that retain an interesting shape or color throughout the winter.  I'm sure they will as this garden is relatively new.  It may get an "excellent" from me next year.

It also is a very good site for viewing attractive ways to incorporate zuni bowls and other methods of water diversion into your landscape. 

Late spring, summer and fall are probably more interesting to the general public.   It is still small, so don't expect to spend hours here.

Nicely laid out, quite compact (5acres), this garden is only 5 years old. There is a central grouping of fruit trees, with a combination of native plants along with plants that grow well/ are popular in this area. There is another area, located across an arroyo from the main garden, whose focus is on plants cultivated and/or used by First Nations and Hispanic settlers. The focus in this garden is plants used for food, medicine, or clothing. Very interesting. As mentioned, the garden is small but definitely worth an hour or two of your time. When we were there there was a special exhibit of sculptures by members of the Namingha family, who are well known artists in this area. The sculptures were beautifully arranged and well worth seeing.

This place always has something special going on. From plays to events associated with the other museums. I have bought books and cards in the gift shop and enjoyed the musings from a knowdgeable staff.
A necessary part of any trip up to Museum Hill.  Beautiful flowers, trees, sculptures. A great place for a easy and beautiful walk

If  you are into the garden and want to understand more about the local plants -- visit this spot.  It is worth an hour or so to wander around and see what is featured or what looks the best in the season you happened to be there.  As  you would suspect lots of water tolerant plants -- including a few that I had not thought of even though I have a cactus and succulent back yard design.  Be sure to mention it if you are a member of your local arboretum -- then the admission is free as they are part of the national association.
Loved the sculptures nestled among  the plants at the Botanic Garden. The garden is just across the road from the museum s and you can walk to them.

name: Santuario De Nuestra Senora de Guadalupe
reviews: Beautiful grounds to stroll and great photo ops! Some grade changes, but easy to get around if you are somewhat limited in walking.

My husband and I visited this church when we were visiting Santa Fe in September, 2019.  It was not open but we could walk around the outside and enjoy the beautiful architecture.  The rose garden is beautiful, too.  This church is worth a visit whem in Santa Fe.

This is a very simple, but beautiful church that you should visit.  The roses outside the main door are absolutely gorgeous and they were in full bloom when we were there the second week of June.  Take time to stop and appreciate the vibrant colors of the roses and this lovely place of worship.
Beautiful grounds to stroll and great photo ops! Some grade changes, but easy to get around if you are somewhat limited in walking.

If you want a very short walk to stretch your legs, or want to buy a souvenir, or a cup of coffee, or a meal, you would benefit by stopping on the High Road to Taos. There are 2 churches, a small park and shops to visit. That is all.

My husband and I visited this church when we were visiting Santa Fe in September, 2019.  It was not open but we could walk around the outside and enjoy the beautiful architecture.  The rose garden is beautiful, too.  This church is worth a visit whem in Santa Fe.

Santa Fe's religious history is embedded in its culture and this lovely church is a piece of that.  It is the oldest shrine to Our Lady of Guadalupe in the country and was beautifully restored after about 200 years.
This is a beautiful place to visit and spend some time in quiet.  So much faith has made this a must-see on any visit to Santa Fe.
